bibl.title: Letter from [Jefferson Randolph Kean] to C. H. Ellis, June 18, 1909

div1.p: [Kean] informs Ellis about the military service of John R. Kissinger and gives details of Kissinger's participation in the yellow fever experiments. Included is a note by Truby. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from [Jefferson Randolph Kean] to C. H. Ellis, June 18, 1909

WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
WASHINGTON. June 18, 1909
Dr. C. H. Ellis, Manager,
United Fruit Company,
New Orleans, La.
Sir:
div1.p:
I am directed by the Surgeon General to acknowledge receipt
of your letter of June 15 asking for information with reference to
John R. Kissinger, formerly a private, Hospital Corps. U.S. Army.

The records of this office show that John R. Kissinger en-
listed in the Hospital Corps. U.S. Army, November 15, 1898, at Indian-
apolis, Ind., having previously served in Co. “D”. of the 157th
Indiana Volunteer Infantry.

While serving at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, he volunteered for
duty at Camp Lazear, the experimental camp which Major Walter Reed,
Surgeon, U.S. Army, the head of US Board for the study of yellow
fever had established for the purpose of experimenting in inocula-
tion. He was, from the report of Dr. Reed, the first volunteer to ?
be bitten by an infected mosquito at that camp. He was first bitten
on November 20, 1900, and the result of this bite being negative.
was again bitten on December 5th, in consequence of which he suf-
fered an attack of yellow fever of moderate severity.

Upon recovery from this attack, he was, for his courageous conduct
in this matter promoted Acting Hospital Steward on recommendation of
the Chief Surgeon of the Department, and also presented with a gold
watch and chain and a sum of money, by authority of the Military Gov-
ernor of Cuba. The gold watch, suitably inscribed, was publicly pre-

sented to him by the Chief Surgeon of the Division of Cuba, and in the
presence of the Medical Officers and Hospital Corps Detachment at
Columbia Barracks. He was also given three months furlough. His
application therefor being endorsed by Major Walter Reed as follows:
“This application meets with my most earnest approval. Acting Hos-
pital Steward Kissinger volunteered on November 20, 1900, without
hope of any pecuniary reward, but solely for the benefit of humanity
and medical science, to be infected by mosquitoes that had purposely
been contaminated by biting cases of yellow fever. In this way he
contracted, on Dec. 8, 1900, a well pronounced attack of yellow fever
from which he is now convalescing. The moral courage exhibited by this
soldier in submitting himself to experimentation is unsurpassed in the
annals of the United States.”

The writer of this letter was associated with these experiments
in an administrative way, as the funds given by General Leonard Wood
for conducting them was placed in his hands for disbursement. As
Chief Surgeon of the Military Department in which the experiments were
being conducts, he had also personal knowledge of the facts connected
with these experiments and is therefore in a position to state of his
personal knowledge that Private Kissinger submitted to these experi-
✓ ments without any expectation or desire for financial reward and the
watch and small sum of money (about $100), which was given a number of
months afterwards, was of the nature of a testimonial rather than
a reward. His case is a very deserving one and this office hopes
that he may receive the financial assistance, of which it is understood
he is in great need.

The White House, Dec. 5, 1906, called the attention of Congress to the
propriety of recognizing the services of the men who took part in the
yellow fever experiments. His message was printed in Senate Document
No. 10, 59th Congress, Second Session.
Mr. Higginson's letter is returned herewith.
